title: Neither Media nor people do any research.
selftext:
You can disagree with rights/policies, but it pisses me off that it is brushed off as western idea.

Twitter has been trending because CJI DY Chandrachud said Indian law provides for self-identification of Gender. News outlets, including the legal news outlets like Bar and Bench, LiveLaw, quoted him without stating that it is Indian Law as established by 2014 judgement by two different judges, 2019 Act and 2020 Rule.

In 2014  Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment published a report by Expert Committee. Relying on that report, Justice KS Radhakrishnan & AK Sikri passed a judgement in the [NLSA v. Union of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Legal_Services_Authority_v._Union_of_India) case in 2014. The verdict recognized the right to  the right to self-identification of their gender as male, female or third gender.

Following this, Parliament passed [Transgender Persons (Protection of Rights) Act of 2019](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transgender_Persons_(Protection_of_Rights)_Act,_2019). The Act initially dilute the right to self-identify gender. But that was changed by the [2020 Rule](https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/gender-self-identification-law-india-7383108/), allowing self-identification of Gender.

Yet, the majority thinks we are "importing" Western/American ideology. Well, India did it in 2014. Even today, the US doesn't have the right to self-identify nationally. LGBT people have been demanding for the right in US, but they don't have it. Council of Europe just passed a non-binding resolution in 2015. Why do you assume we are coping the West? Why do you assume a CJI who studied in US can only think about it? Both the Judges in NLSA cases were Indian students.

Historically too, we have treated our Transgender citizens better than US. So, why do people simply assume it's an US idea? Why is that LGBT movement in India has been through the lense of US/West? If at all you want to comment on LGBT issues, why don't you see Indian history? Why are you relying on Western commenters?

AIDS Bhedbhav Virodhi Andolan published a manifesto in 1991, "Less Than Gay: A Citizens' Report on the Status of Homosexuality in India", calling for marriage equality. IN 1991!! Netherlands was the first country to do so in 2001. US was the 16th country to do so, in 2015. Yes, I know court filings cite US ruling, it's because our Article 14 includes the US Equal Protection Clause. And, US recognized marriage equality because they found prohibition to be violation of BOTH Equal Protection Clause and another clause. Countries that follow common law system cite each other all the time. Botswana cited our [Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navtej_Singh_Johar_v._Union_of_India) in their judgement, if I am correct.

BTW, Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India was in 2018, but our first attempt was in 1994. This was before Lawrence v. Texas (2003), the US equivalent of  Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India. So, if you oppose find a better argument, don't belittle as people who are copying Americans and Europeans.
